attributes.background:
Extracted from Sky News
The family of the charity fundraiser Jane Tomlinson, who died of cancer last month, has demanded a review of the way patients are given access to experimental treatments.
Her relatives say she was denied a potentially lifesaving drug in the months before her death, even though it was available in other parts of the country.
They want the government to end what has been called the postcode lottery of NHS treatment.

Speaking at a news conference in Leeds, Mrs Tomlinson's husband Mike revealed that his wife had to travel to Nottingham to receive the cancer drug Lapatinib, after her NHS Trust said it would not fund the £6,700 drug.
Mother-of-three Mrs Tomlinson, 43, lost her seven-year battle with cancer in September.
Despite her illness she raised more than £1.75m for charity through a series of gruelling endurance events
